importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was published, indicating the current state of the federal shutdown and the imminent risk to food stamp benefits in November.
The start date of the federal government shutdown, which has led to the financial crisis in food assistance programs like SNAP and WIC.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which food stamp benefits are at risk of running out, with the USDA indicating funds will be depleted in two weeks.
The timeframe during which the USDA is advising states to delay issuing November benefits due to funding shortfalls.

keyTakeAways: Approximately 42 million Americans are at risk of losing access to food stamps in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has declared that food stamp benefits will run out in two weeks if the shutdown continues.
A key reason for the funding gap is that the SNAP program’s estimated $8 billion in November benefits exceed the available $6 billion in contingency funds.
The Trump administration has not committed to covering the shortfall and has instead blamed Democrats for political obstruction.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the administration for halting food stamp payments, calling it a deliberate act that harms vulnerable families.
WIC, another nutrition program, was temporarily protected by a $300 million shift from tariff revenue, but that revenue is insufficient to cover SNAP.
17 states have stopped accepting new food stamp applications due to financial constraints in their systems.
The situation is not unprecedented—similar issues occurred during the 2018 shutdown, where a legal workaround was used to avoid benefit cuts.
Advocacy groups warn that the lack of funding during Thanksgiving poses a severe threat to food security and will strain food pantries.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Agriculture Secretary under the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She announced the food stamp program will run out of money in two weeks and blamed Democrats for the shutdown, making her a central figure in the administration’s response.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, emphasizing the harm to vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: USDA (United States Department of Agriculture)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for food assistance programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA issued warnings that SNAP benefits will run dry and advised states to delay payments, directly impacting food security.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the largest federal nutrition assistance program, with 42 million Americans at risk of losing benefits in November.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Women, Infants, and Children program)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal nutrition program for pregnant women, new mothers, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue shift, but it highlights the broader crisis in funding for all nutrition programs.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal government leadership during the shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is responsible for the political blame placed on Democrats and the lack of contingency funding for SNAP.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party opposing the Republican-led shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of prioritizing political agendas over food security, and are also blamed for failing to negotiate a spending deal that includes expanded Obamacare subsidies.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party that opposed the spending deal and contributed to the shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of unwillingness to compromise, leading to the funding gap that threatens SNAP and WIC.

namedEntities.name: Thanksgiving
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The timing of the benefit cutoff is especially damaging as it coincides with Thanksgiving, a time when food insecurity is most acute.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was used to sustain WIC, but not sufficient to cover SNAP, illustrating a funding shortfall across key nutrition programs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amid a federal government shutdown that began on October 1, 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture warns that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, will run out of funds by November, putting approximately 42 million Americans at risk of losing critical food assistance. The USDA has stated that its $6 billion contingency fund is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits. While the Trump administration has previously provided emergency funding for other programs, it has not committed to continuing SNAP benefits, instead blaming Democrats for political obstruction. A shift in tariff revenue helped sustain the WIC program but not SNAP. The situation has led 17 states to halt new food stamp applications, and advocacy groups warn that the lack of benefits during Thanksgiving will severely impact food security. Governor Kathy Hochul has condemned the administration's decision to suspend benefits as a deliberate act harming vulnerable families, underscoring the broader political and humanitarian consequences of the shutdown.
title: Millions of Americans at risk of losing food stamps next month amid shutdown
